content.question: ​The Richter scale is a numerical scale that uses base <math alttext="10"><semantics><mn>10</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> logarithms for measuring an earthquake’s magnitude. The larger the number, the more intense the earthquake. As intensities increase multiplicatively by a factor of <math alttext="10"><semantics><mn>10</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>, the Richter scale increases additively by <math alttext="1"><semantics><mn>1</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>. Consider two earthquakes that occurred in the year 2022. An earthquake in Indonesia had a magnitude of <math alttext="5.1"><semantics><mn>5.1</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>, and an earthquake in Mexico had a magnitude of  <math alttext="2.5"><semantics><mn>2.5</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>. Approximately how many times more intense was the Indonesia earthquake than the Mexico earthquake?
